content.body: mcarter_: have you done a write-up anywhere yet on your implementation related to the connection API?
PlotKit is interesting, but also lacking in a bunch of features
for example, vertical gridlines
annevk: please send feedback to the list, not the irc channel :-)
This internet access saga is truly bizarre (but it works again now, so hey)
Hixie, ok, e-mailed you + www-archive
It feels weird sending emails to Hixie without www-archive :P
annevk: thanks
geez
twitter is slower than ever (besides when it's unresponsive)
Woo Hoo! This book is finally available for pre-order. http://www.amazon.com/Ultimate-HTML-Reference-Ian-Lloyd/dp/0980285887/
I was one of the technical reviewers for it as it was being written
Lachy: What makes it ultimater than the thousands of other HTML books? :-)
cause I reviewed it and know it's good :-)
That kind of appeal to authority is not very convincing :-p
For one reason, unlike many other books that teach people to use XHTML, this one actually teaches both HTML and XHTML and gives good advice about the use of both.
there's a public beta online here http://reference.sitepoint.com/html
hmm. It seems to be missing entity references.
oh well, that can be added to the next revision
Hixie, yt?
Hixie, the entity reference table in the spec is missing the <tbody> after the first row
w3c or whatwg?
whatwg
I didn't check the w3c copy of the spec
I only noticed in the whatwg copy cause I was copying the table for use in the html authoring guide
w3c too iirc
I'm going to rewrite it to make it more author friendly
oh, i see what you're saying
odd
if possible, can you send mail?
i'm in the middle of a painful edit
sure
thanks
Hixie, do you use a script to generate that table?
yes
Can I get a copy of it, so I can modify it to generate a more appropriate table for the author guide.
it's one of my first ever python scripts, so i dunno :-)
LOL
http://junkyard.damowmow.com/322
that script is then called using this bash magic:
wget -o /dev/null -N http://www.w3.org/2003/entities/2007xml/unicode.xml
[ unicode.xml -nt entities-unicode.inc ] && nice -n 19 python .entity-processor.py > .new-entities-unicode.inc
[ -s .new-entities-unicode.inc ] && mv -f .new-entities-unicode.inc entities-unicode.inc
cat entities-* | sort | uniq > entities.inc
thanks
and entities-* matches the entities-unicode.inc file mentioned above and entities-legacy.inc
http://www.whatwg.org/specs/web-apps/current-work/entities-legacy.inc
which is a hard-coded list of entities
Hixie, doing more work on sandboxing?
yeah
the http://www.whatwg.org/specs/web-apps/current-work/index-diff file shows what i have so far
Hixie, for seamless it should probably say something about initial containing block and such too
othermaciej: the problem with making item() available, etc, is that you lose the ability to use the data-item="" attribute
it does
unless i messed up the commit
search for "initial containing block" in html5 and there are two occurances, both doing what you just asked for :-)
it sets the height tozero...
right
it doesn't entirely remove it
hmm
you can't remove it
that would break css in pretty fundamental ways
it's like saying we should remove the root element
what would it even mean?
it means that the initial containing block of the nested browsing context is that of the browsing context
well, that's what I thought it would specify
Hixie: yeah, I can see why it could cause conflicts
annevk: wow, that would be weird
now absolutely positioning stuff still goes against the nested browsing context initial containing block, which is not what you want (not always anyway)
why wouldn't it be what you want?
it's still an iframe
you can't render outside the iframe
if you could you'd be open to all kinds of weird hacks
if you could you'd have the client-side includes people have been looking for
i don't think client side include requests have really been looking for ways to render outside the box
they mostly just want to include their navigation links or header or footer
btw, in the short definition for the sandbox attribute you should note that giving it values means you lift restrictions
I prefer what Hixie currently has
we don't want to make handling of the IFRAMEd content too weird
Hixie, maybe split "xxx_origin_please_suggest_a_better_name" into "dom-access" and "storage-access"
annevk: sandbox="dom-access" doesn't convey what it does, since even with sandbox="", DOM access is still possible, just not from other documents, even if their URIs are in the same origin
annevk: and storage access (and XHR, etc) is allowed if scripting is enabled, it just doesn't work (since the document isn't in the expected origin)
localStorage would actually still work and end up in void, or not?
maybe just "default-origin" or some such then?
Hixie, btw, these two comments make it much more clear for some reason what the attribute is supposed to do then the note in the spec
yeah i dunno how to explain it
maybe localStorage should fail if the origin is an identifier and not a tuple
hmm, StorageEvent.uri should be StorageEvent.url ...
one day I'll have to figure out what the difference between a URL and a URI is. Wouldn't want to embarrass myself in public
Don't forget IRI
oh yeah, I discovered those recently. Mad
and URN
"URI" is the term you use when talking to standards people so you look clever, and "URL" is the term you use when talking to normal people so you're understood
lol
<input type=url> was at one point type=uri...
i plan to change the spec to use the term "url"
and just define "url" in the terminology section as being an iri
i expect this will cause the nitpickers to have enough heart attacks to keep them off our back for a few months
(actually, not just an iri. it will depend on the character encoding in weird ways.)
Hixie: Also define uri as url, then
hmm, URL5 :)
Dashiva: what does that mean?
Hixie: Just in case there's a URI left in there somewhere, it should be defined :)
othermaciej, there's a difference between style.foo = x and storage.foo = x
othermaciej, for style.foo to work foo has to bedefined on the CSS2Properties interface
othermaciej, storage.foo will always work (though maybe not when foo matches some existing member)
Dashiva: it's easy to ensure there isn't :-)
is utterly tangled up in a mess of defining scripting enabled/disabled on a per-browsing-context basis instead of globally

annevk: sure, it is a predefined list instead of completely open-ended, but CSS styles do have the concept of adding and removing properties, and those properties are reflected directly as JS-level properties
i agree with anne that it's not the same
"'opacity' in style" is always true
it doesn't become false when the property is removed
"removeProperty" is a misnomer from the JS point of view
i'm not wedded to the 'delete' syntax, but i think your argument that it's the wrong semantic is not valid
the style declaration example is not to illustrate that it is the wrong semantic
it is to illustrate that, in general, you can reasonably have custom getters and setters without custom deleters
and this will not confuse people
i don't think it would confuse people
that was roc's argument
that if you don't have custom delete, you shouldn't even have custom get and set
i just think that in this particular case, it makes sense to offer custom delete
it's custom *add* that I really think deserves a matching custom delete
I assume setting it to undefined to delete was considered and rejected, what was the reasoning?
setting it to "undefined" would set it to the string "undefined"
set and add have the same syntax in JS
as currently defined
othermaciej: style.foo = 'baz' is matched by delete style.foo, for non-valid values of 'foo'
of course they have the same syntax, that's part of the problem ehre
Hixie: or indeed, for any object it is true that when the setter does nothing special, delete works normally
right
so why is this different?
well, it's not usually the case that when the setter *does* do something special, delete still works normally
(or beyond that, delete does something correspondingly special)
i don't think we've ever really had an equivalent interface before
except maybe NamedNodeMap, which imho is poorly designed
but like i said, i don't really care much about this
I don't care that much about the semantic argument, except that I think having custom delete is a small improvement, and supporting it correctly is potentially a nontrivial burden
Are there any common cases where you'd be deleting stuff often?
I figure if you're setting a property for storage you're likely to keep it. Maybe it'll be unused (e.g. set to nothing) in periods, but the use for the property isn't going to disappear
I will admit to being a little biased, in that the crazy dynamicity of JS makes me want to cling to any shred of statically determined behavior
I think delete is not going to be nearly as common as set/add or get, but it seems plausible
(in the style case too I would guess you set a lot more often than you remove)

well, the ie/ff argument is a strong one -- what we really should be asking is whether the ff team and the ie team plan to remove the custom getting when they switch from globalStorage to localStorage
I don't really know why custom delete would be a big burden if you already support custom add
Because add is actually set?
in syntax it is
custom code running at set time is something we already have to live with
but implementation-wise, not really
or not necessarily
both due to DOM APIs and due to supporting the Mozilla getter/setter extension to ECMAScript
BTW I almost always see style.opacity = ''; rather than removeProperty
Because they're equivalent in practice
Dashiva: It seems like there would be lots of cases where you wanted to persist some property for a certian amount of time (e.g. till the network becomes available) and then stop persisting it
jgraham: Sure, and later when the network becomes unavailable again, you'd want to persist that same property with a new value
custom code at delete time (in particular, JS executing as a result of the event dispatch) would be new
it's not impossible to handle
but every additional bit of operator overloading makes the language harder to optimize
Dashiva: In that sort of case I would tend to delete stuff rather than set it to some magic value (e.g. the empty string)
jgraham: Because the case is very rare, right?
I don't think 'delete' is going to make any material difference to the optimizability of JS
No just because it feels like cleaning up your storage area is the right thing to do
Yes, and you want to clean up because you don't expect to use it in the near future
I guess that depends what near future means
What I'm trying to claim is that if you use a property often enough that you'd benefit from delete shorthand, you're using it often enough that you're likely to be just nullifying the value instead
roc: every statement that can run arbitrary code invalidates many assumptions
currently when you see this code:
var x = 1;
since 'set' and 'get' are already in that class
delete z.y;
you can assume x has the same value afterwards
that game is already over
othermaciej: no you can't
othermaciej: z.y might run a getter
(Only on z, right?)
I think you're going to have to stretch really hard to find a realistic testcase where optimizing around deletes is important and there are no gets/sets in the way

Dashiva: I don't have a strong opinion on that. I guess my Python bias makes me think that delete is a reasonable syntax for this case but it's dangerous to apply reasoning from one language in another
Hixie: ok, if z is a local variable or parameter you can
even if you come up with one, the problem is still completely dwarfed by gets/sets, so I still find it hard to care
roc: sure, I don't think it will be common, but the other crazy dynamic things in the language suck so much that on principle I am against additional overloading
othermaciej: well, get IE and FF (or at least one of them) to not support delete when they switch to localStorage
I don't really want to engage in a majority vote power struggle, I just wanted to express the downsides of overloading the delete operator (particularly in a way that runs JS code)
othermaciej: (right now you can't tell from the spec that 'delete' is supposed to do anything, it's just an [XXX] marker)
I appreciate your principles but it really is too late to apply them to JS
it's not as bad as overloading * or && would be
how do I see the output from the assert statements in python? Is there some debug mode I need to turn on or something?
roc: it is certainly possible to infer useful knowledge from some of the operators that are still not overloaded
Lachy: You don't unless the expression evaluates to False
othermaciej: my point is that even if i agreed with you, i wouldn't be able to do anything about it at this point really
othermaciej: since the spec doesn't actually explicitly mention this at all right now
oh, ok. The python docs aren't clear about that at all
othermaciej: yeah, absolutely
if they eval to False you'll get an AssertionError raised
othermaciej: (also, note that overloading [[Delete]] is explicitly supported by the ES spec, unlike overloading the * or && operators)
other areas of the language aren't as goofy as properties
(I would again point to * and && as examples, boy would it suck if those depended on the input types)
well
* already does, if you're optimizing hard
starts seeing the light at the end of his scripting-disabled-per-browsing-context tunnel of doom
hm
i wonder if parsing changes if i set designMode

for * you know the result is a number and you know it always converts to number and multiplies as number - skipping conversions or optimizing for a subset of numbers based on additional knowledge can indeed help, but it is not as bad as +
Hixie: I have made my case, I am not really inclined to lobby implementors beyond that
(I would reserve that for more important issues)
othermaciej: Implement it yourself then ;)
obviously we should have a new mozDelete JS operator
othermaciej: at least one of the vendors hasn't even heard your case (microsoft aren't on the whatwg list)
Dashiva: WebKit already implements localStorage
gets a steady stream of html4all e-mails written by RB
othermaciej: so i'm not sure what you're expecting to have happen
thinks it's time to go to bed
othermaciej: Hmm. It's hard to not implement delete any more than you already have, then.
Brady actually implemented delete but I'd like to encourage him to remove it
sigh, ie8 throws an exception saying you can't get document.designMode if you try to set it (not get it) while parsing

Hixie: I am not expecting anything, I am just declining the action item of trying to persuade other implementors to do or not do anything specific when they implement localStorage (beyond stating the facts)
RB has an interesting idea of use-cases
othermaciej: ok
Hixie: but I can forward the thread to public-html if you think that would be helpful
othermaciej: i don't really know what would be helpful. the spec will have to require [Delete] support of the browsers support it, though
othermaciej: so at the end of the day, it _is_ a majority vote
wonders about the IE extensions to storage
Hixie: honestly I am more worried about whether Firefox and IE will transition to localStorage at all, or if we'll end up having to also implement globalStorage in WebKit
hopefully IE can since they are still just a beta but who knows?
i hope ff does, since they were the reason we changed the api
i have little hope of anything convenient to the health of the web coming from the IE team
i mean, they couldn't even implement globalStorage without embrace-and-extending it
even if they don't mean to, they seem to just act that way out of habbit
it does seem kind of habitual
othermaciej: Should it really say prefix twice? "This class is designed to carry a prefix but match exclusively on the prefix and namespaceURI"

Hixie: Is it meant to be non-conforming if scripts cause an invalid state at any point during their execution, or only when they've finished? (e.g. if you do "img = document.createElement('img'); document.body.appendChild(img); img.src = '...'" is it non-conforming because there's (temporarily) an invalid state (with a srcless img)?)
uh let me fix that hold on
reads starts a read-through of r1643 <iframe sandbox> diff
Good luck with that :-)
just skimmed it to see if there were any obvious changes like an ASCII art elephant graphic
Philip`: fixed
Hixie: Thanks

notes that http://dev.w3.org/cvsweb/html5/spec/Overview.html.diff?r1=1.830&r2=1.831&f=h provides side-by-side colored diff for those who like such things (I like the html5.org web-apps tracker view better myself...)
Hixie: It seems unfair to only exempt automated conformance checkers from interpreting the author's intent - non-automated ones might be equally unable to interpret intent in some cases
I don't like how it selects the entire line with the background color
Lots of font tags there, ho
smiles at <font face="Helvetica,Arial" size="-1"> </font>

e.g. I might submit a document written in Lojban to a non-automated conformance checking service, and they could point out lots of non-machine-checkable issues (like if I used <b> instead of <h1>) but couldn't possibly check all the issues (like if the alt text was a decent alternative to the image)
I don't like the idea of conformance checkers anyway, I'd prefer conformance chess
If you lose, your page is deleted?
Philip`: why couldn't a human determine if the page had good alt text?
or rather, not good, but spec-compliant alt text
If he doesn't know the language
one would need to know the language to correctly assess conformance of a document
just like one would need more than 2 bytes of memory to correctly assess conformance of a document
sees a challenge!
How much cache do I get?
none
Darn
2 bytes memory total
including registers
and I/O
Address space?
one bit address space, 0 addresses the first byte, 1 addresses the second.

you actually could do it in a conforming way -- just invoke the "User agents may impose implementation-specific limits on otherwise unconstrained inputs" rule to say that you only check documents up to 2 bytes
and always say it'ss non-conforming
but that's not the point! :-P
With enough disk space, and enough exams to procrastinate, I'm sure I could cook up something insane
no disk space, you have 2 bytes total
for everything
program, data, cache, registers, everything
I have this vague feeling we've deviated from the initial problem statement somewhat
including the video RAM
my point was just that there are minimum requirements for determining conformance
one of those is (for non-automated checkers) knowign the language
The service wouldn't be certifying conformance, it would just be helping me improve the quality of my document, so it's useful even if it isn't complete
sure
web browsers are useful even when they're not conforming too
conformance isn't a minimum requirement for usefulness
not by a long shot
goes to bed :-)
nn :-)
hm, <iframe sandbox> for the first time introduces the concept of a document's origin changing while the document is up
you could do   var e = iframe.contentDocument.documentElement; iframe.setAttribute('sandbox', '');
at that point, you can navigate 'e' fine, but if you try to read anything from e.parentNode, you get an exception
good times
doesn't document.domain do that too?
oh, i guess so
yeah, fair enough
thankfully that's the only other one
though that one just changes the "effective origin" not the true origin
effective origin is what matters, no?
er, "effective script origin"
for sec
depends what for
per spec document.domain doesn't affect where you can take images from for <canvas>, for instance
and the rules for which browsing contexts you can navigate aren't affected by document.domain per spec
oh, yeah

and if you meta refresh to an http uri that redirects to a javascript: uri, the javascript: uri compares the original origin to the redirecting uri's origin to decide whether to run or not (and then runs in the same global context, but fails almost immediately since it can't get to anything on the Window or Document objects since it has a different effective script origin)
hm, maybe that is a bug
anyway
the Web security model is going to be promising job security for us for years to come
hah
hmm
changing the principal on a document actually sounds very scary
that might be something to avoid if we can
I think it's impossible to do that
do it, or avoid it?
avoid changing the principal
we could just say that dynamic changes to 'sandbox' don't have any effect until a new document is loaded in the iframe
that doesn't address document.domain
but that seems like a good idea anyway
roc: yeah, maybe
roc: once i've sent out the e-mail where i say i added this, please do send any feedback you have :-)
it'll likely be a few hours or days yet though
our feedback on that should come from boris
that's good too :-)
this is all highly speculative stuff
no rush or anything on any of this
(sandbox="" or seamless="")
these are features people have been asking for for years
yeah
I guess you saw the Mozilla bug
indeed
speccing this stuff was basically impossible until recent weeks, because it depends on so much of the previously unspecified stuff in really core ways
i mean, it depends on the navigation model, on multiple windows, on how scripts run, on same-origin... it's got its tentacles all over the stuff that didn't ever get acknowledged before HTML5
these features may in fact be the first real author-visible tangible benefits of having this spec be this detailed
fights the urge to make a bad pun on the mailing list
why fight it
because I'm not sure I have much more that's useful to say at the same time
at least not if we wanted the test harness to be usable in current browsers
"Require that Henri do the impossible by checking that scripts never cause non-conforming states to occur." great
hsivonen, his various definitions of compatible are pretty strict
hsivonen, probably needs more ~ usage :)

The difficult, important, and often overlooked part of a version identification strategy is specifying the meaning and interpretation when a consumer encounters a version identifier it does not know about."
that's actually not just true for versioning :)
I think it is good that the doc acks that version identifiers aren't necessary, but it would be better to say that they are actually harmful
yes
maybe we should comment
one day y'all will realise the true value of TAG findings...
hsivonen: it wasn't really a major change to what we understood the spec to say anyway, i just hadn't realised that we hadn't made conformance checkers check for all conformance states
hsivonen: it doesn't really affect you at all
is it greater than the value of TAG losings?
Hixie: as I said before, Dave Orchard's presentation about compatibility was good stuff before he got to applying it to XSD (it was XSD's fault that it wasn't as good from there on)
Hixie: I was just pointing out to annevk where the same reasoning is written down
aargh. I accidentally introduced a lot of bugs with Eclipse's refactoring tools
Undo
roc: that would break a lot of good stuff too
Redo :-)
fortunately, I have a way of identiying the problematic points
Right click -> Remove Bugs (ctrl+alt+shift+r)
what were the attributes we'd come up with for replacing data: URIs on <iframe>s?
html=""
markup=""
content=""
aren't data URIs more compatible?
or do we want incompatibility for security?
data: URIs require too much thinking
you have to escape too many characters (three four to be minimally safe, more to be compliant)
and you don't get much backcompat anyway
since IE doesn't support them
Hixie: by the time anyone ships a sandbox, IE8, Firefox, Safari and Opera together will be a big legacy

a new attribute only really desperately needs one character escaped (the delimiter -- typically " => &quot) and for correctness the ampersand (& => &) though the latter isn't security-critical, and the former is very obvious if you get it wrong
ah crap, <meta> has stolen content="" already it seems
IE8 doesn't support <iframe src="data:text/html,..."> either
at least not in beta1
(acid3 tries to take care of that, but that's not likely to be seen until IE9)
(and that's assuming a major IE8.5 between 8 and 9)
I like content="" the best
"src", "source", "src2", "content", "value", and "data" are all vetoed
doc="" is currently leading the pack
with html="" a close second
will it accept only HTML fragments or XML too?
HTML
that violates some principle you had initially
which one?
that uas wouldn't be required to support both parsers if they didn't want to
UAs wouldn't be
so XML UAs may ignore doc=""?
time to disassemble my code and count the bytes again...
i dunno :-)
doc="" doesn't exist
it's just an idea
i don't really want to skew this just to make the xml crowd happy
since in practice nobody will use the xml version
htmldoc=""
or type=""
there are various options
lets not overload type even more :)
does <iframe> have a type=""?
Hixie, I think it does in HTML4
cool
well then
we just use that
checks...
doesn't seem like it...
does have longdesc :)
actually, it doesn't
w00t. only 7933 bytes
what problem is this new attribute trying to solve?
if it doesn't have it, then i say we're fine with using it for our piurposes
which new attribute?
the one you're discussing adding to iframe
doc="" or type=""?
doc="" solves the problem of there not being any good safe way to embed content inline in a sandbox
making type conforming will led to confusion when it is not used together with doc
lets call it doctype=""
type="" solves the theoretical problem of not being able to decide whether doc="" is html or xml or text/plain or png...
annevk: :-P
ok, so it's a backwards incompatible replacement for data URIs that provides security in new browsers without compromising older ones.
data: URIs don't really provide what we need here, so it's not a replacement for them
data: URIs are too complicated to correctly escape to really be a good security solution
I don't really like the idea of embedding markup within an attribute
do you have a better idea?
but I have no alternative solution
i agree that it's suboptimal
alternatively we could put it inside <iframe> ...
though maybe that's more icky for authors than just escaping "
is the proposal do be able to include fragments of HTML in them like this:
content inside <iframe> has REALLY obscure escaping semantics
Lachy: yes
Lachy: well, that's a variant of hte proposal
i'm writing it up in more detail in the e-mail i'm sending
I assume authors won't need to include <!DOCTYPE html> in the fragment?
we could make that implicit, probably
and it would only allow elements that are valid within <body>
hy?
why, even
hm. I guess that's not necessary
putting unescaped markup in a quoted string seems like it makes it easy to accidentally terminate the attribute value early
(or maliciously)
othermaciej: luckily, that is trivially detectable, and easy to solve
othermaciej: even without security attacks, people will use " or ' in their comments and thus it'll be caught quickly
othermaciej: and the delimiter is the only character you absolutely must escape
I thought your major argument against some approaches to inline sandboxing was that they still require (minimal) escaping
my objections were that they required non-trivial or easy-to-get-wrong escaping.
people would be motivated to get this right for reasons other than just security
escaping case-insensitive </sandbox> is not very hard, though certainly possible to get wrong
since getting it wrong would break the entire page the moment someone used a quote or apostrophe (as appropriate)
othermaciej: sure but people don't type </sandbox> in as a matter of course
othermaciej: so there it becomes _only_ a security problem
othermaciej: and since it's more than one character, you end up with problems with over-long utf-8 sequences, embedded nulls, all kinds of stuff like that
othermaciej: none of which affects a single quote mark
well the overlong utf-8 might i guess
you have to normalize in any case
(unicode normalize)
(or reject input that is not in normal form already)
who does?
as far as i can tell, with the doc="" idea everyone or anyone can forget to normalise and you're still ok
whoever is escaping quotes
(i.e. whoever processes the input after receiving it from an untrusted source but before putting it in the attribute value)
why?
escaping </sandbox> would not cut it btw, consider </sandbox >
would escaping "</sandbox" cut it?
Hixie: to successfully escape denormal close quotes?
or am I missing the point of your "overlong utf-8" remark?
You could easily forget to escape "</sandbox" case-insensitively
case-insensitive </sandbox might, but then so would </iframe i suppose
still, " seems a lot easier
it is easier, but the attribute approach has the big downside that you need an iframe per item to be sandboxed, and iframes are heavyweight
so if we can countenance some escaping of untrusted content being required, I'd rather see a version that is usable for hundreds or thousands of items
Heavyweightedness is just an implementation bug :-)
othermaciej: i'm confused. I'm talking about encoding U+0022 as, e.g., 0xC0 0xA2.
othermaciej: which has nothing to do with unicode normalisation forms
Hixie: then I apologize for using the terminology incorrectly
othermaciej, ah yeah, creating hundreds of document objects is costly
not really sure how to do something smarter than that though
Philip`: some of the heavyweightedness of iframe is effectively required by specs
othermaciej: all the workable sandboxing approaches i've seen so far invoke new browsing contexts (iframes)
afaict with <sandbox> you have the same issue, no?
othermaciej: the only differences between the working proposals i've seen is how they encode the data
othermaciej: i don't understand how to do origin isolation without a separate browsing context
Hixie: I agree you can't do a sandbox with any scripting enabled without a separate browsing context
(not feasibly anyway)
I think you can do a noscript sandbox without an extra browsing context or document
it's not just scripting
e.g. target="" and forms would need very complicated and subtle changes to be done safely without an iframe
and i'm not confident that i could spec those precisely enough to avoid introducing security bugs into the spec
and i'm certainly not willing to take on the responsibility for spec-mandated security holes in humanity's most widely deployed application platform :-)
i can't afford the legal fees, for one
i hope you have some protection against that regardless :)
I think for the use case of the inline sandbox (blog comments or the like) it would be ok to totally ban targetted links and form elements (parser discards them)
and if the spec is found to require security holes it will be ignored on that count as I am sure you know
MessageEvent.uri comes to mind :)
though that's more a privacy issue
othermaciej: not before multiple shipping implementations are out there, possibly with content depending on it (e.g. look how far we've gotten with blocking cross-origin <script> or form submissions)

Hixie: Just add a statement "UAs must not contain any security holes" - if the spec also requires certain features which are security holes, then any UA trying to implement HTML5 will necessarily be non-conforming and not your problem any more
For blog comments, could you put the entire comments section in a single sandbox?

disallowing redirect to javascript: is perfectly safe
